transcript.content: Intro plays
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Welcome to the 7th Ricky Gervais Show, on podcast. I'm Ricky Gervais. With me, Steven Merchant.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington.
Alright?
Now, talking of that, that's only five to go then, isn't it? Five to go in this series of twelve?
Still seems a lot though, doesn't it?
We'll- we'll take a little break. I'm sure we'll come back, through popular demand, I'm hoping.
Yep.
I'm hoping to put that on the poster "Back by popular demand!"
Well, I'm hoping it's "By overwhelming public demand", which is my favourite.
Yeah , exactly. Yeah. Yeah. As we're doing it for nothing. We want a little bit of pat on the back, don't we?
Exactly. Please
Do they give awards out for podcasting?

Oh, if they do... Whoo hoo! Hello... I am already riding my speech, baby! I was thinking that everyone listening, if you want to register your email with us, we'll let you know when we're back on air. Maybe later in the year. Go to RickyGervais.com and just register. And then when I do a general mail out, I'll let you all know when Karl Pilkington is back.
You are a good guy to these people, Rick.
No sweat.
Steve laughs
Now there's been an awful lot of correspondence. I mean, it's backing up there. We've got acres of it to get through.

It is a bit mental, actually, but it's very flattering. And thank you all. And people have sent such brilliant things in and spent so much time doing them that someone sent in this mock up of-- We were talking about those Russian sort of iconoclastic artifacts and someone's mocked up Karl Pilkington as Saint Karl The Bewildered.
It's brilliant. It's so good!
Can we put that on the web?

Yeah, I think let's put that up on rickygervais.com and that's from Joanne Murray in Philadelphia. We've also got one, which is little work of art from Ed Ferrari. And it's the three of us in a studio. And it's-- It's just great.
It's very flattering picture of you though, Rick, you look about 14.
I know. I've come out very well in this. Karl has got a head like a fucking orange.
Steve laughs

Look at that! And you, well, I don't know what you are. Your head is about two foot long and in real life it's only 18 inches long, isn't it? So he's exaggerated yours a little bit... But it's a lovely drawing, we'll put that up on the web as well.
Just, uh-- So everyone go to rickygervais.com, everyone register please, and we'll email you. And everyone, keep sending stuff in. So thank you very much!
Karl, Joe from Bradford asks "What body parts can you live without?" He wants to know, he's obviously having sleepless nights thinking about this.
What? So--
Ricky and Steve both sigh
Well, the brain!
He's coped this far.
So the bits that I've got now, if I had to get rid of
Yeah.
One of them
Yep.
What wouldn't I miss?
Yes.
Uhm... I did a bit of an experiment on this, right?
Brilliant
It's my job at home to wash up. Right? Suzanne does--

She gives you all the really big responsible ones! She sort of like pays the bills and wires the house. And you go "What can I do?" And she can go "Well, you can go and play with the worms in the garden."
Yeah.
So anyway, so it's my job to wash up and that. Right? And I thought to sort of make it interesting and stuff... I thought, I wonder if I can do it right if I didn't have any thumbs.
Ricky and Steve laugh
And so what did you do?
So I just sort of-
You sliced off your thumbs.
I just sort of held them in and it's amazing how like, it took me ages... Just having like, that one thing gone.

Well, it's part of our evolution. The opposable thumb. Basically, that's when we soared... These are milestones in human evolution. The opposable thumb that. The forward facing eyes. The upright-- These are massive things in taking us out of the animal kingdom.
And one day, Karl, you'll walk upright!
But what do you mean about eyes facing forward?
You mean before we got here, there was people whose eyes were looking in their head?
Ricky bursts laughing
I don't understand that. Is that what you mean?

No! No, because when we got sort of binocular vision where we could-- We could, you know, because we were-- Predators have a forward faci-- I'm going way back. I'm not just saying-- I'm not saying that. I'm not saying chimps had eyes on the side of their head, but I'm saying big, big, major milestones in any evolution.
Hmmm
I lost you at evolution.
Yeah.

So when you were doing this experiment, washing up, you say that you found it difficult, took you ages. So you didn't just give up once you realized how essential thumbs were, you actually washed up everything.
I just think of Suzanne walking in and Karl's there just covered in water and Fairy liquid suds, standing on a pile of broken crockery.
Yeah. Plunging his face into the sink every 30 seconds and just swishing his head around.
But we talked about the washing up thing before, haven't we? And I stood there washing up. And I sort of look out of a window, so the sinks in front of the window.
Yeah

And that's why I quite like washing up, because I can just look out onto the street, see people going past. There's like a local homeless fella called Franco. You know, I look out that he's all right and everything. But I was looking across the way, right? And there's some-- Sort of- There's some chinese people who live on in a flat, right? Really small flat, and they're up till all hours. I don't know what they're doing...

But they decide to vac up at about half three in the morning. They're always really noisy and that. But above them there was some woman, right? Who-- The sort of bedroom is on par to our kitchen, right?
Yeah.
So I'm sort of washing up and I sort of look across and see-- See this woman with, like, you know, no, no pants on that... No, no bra and that.
Naked.
Yeah. Just..
That's the word you're looking for.

Yeah, yeah. She's just wandering about with naught on and that. So I was like, oh, what's going on here? So I carried on washing up and that, right? And kept looking. And then I was looking and she looked at me, right? So we made eye contact.
Sure.
So I was like, "oh God", right? So what I thought the best thing to do was, was sort of drop me pants a little bit...
Ricky and Steve laugh
Just a little bit. Just like, you know, I had boxer shorts on and that, I thought if I just show a little bit of... Little bit of sort of arse cheek, then it's kind of like, right, we're quits.
I don't understand the thinking!
So Suzanne's watching the telly, right? I think she's watching Sex and the City or something.
Yeah.

She sort of turns around to see how I'm getting on with the washing up, right? She sees me with, like, me pants sort of down a little bit with me arse out. She said, "What are you doing?!" I said "Don't look now!" I said, but there's a woman over the road, right, with no pants on that she caught me looking... I'm just giving her a bit back.
I love the fact that he explains the rules! And Suzanne's meant to go, "Okay!"
Makes sense! But I don't-- So, hang on. So you showed a bit of your arse. You turned, presumably, to show the arse or waggles the arse out the window.
I had to lift it up a little bit on the sort of on the draining board.
What-- Hang on, though. What did she do? Did you register her reaction, when she saw a bit of your arse, what happened?
When she saw my arse?
Yeah.

Well, then I wasn't looking because I thought, in a way, I don't want-- I don't want it to look like "Well, I've seen a bit of your stuff. Here's a bit of mine." I just thought at the end of that, I caught a glance of you.
It's only fair.
You've had a bit back. You know, I'm not making a deal out of it
You see, I genuinely think James Stewart missed a trick here in Rear Window.
Yeah.
This would have been, you know, a much better film, had James Stewart just popped his pants down.
It would have given a whole new meaning to the title 'Rear Window'.
Yeah, exactly!

It's tricky, though. I seem to be surrounded by people like that because I've told you before, there's the old woman across the way who's just sat there reading a book. I looked through everybody's windows like that. Remember that film, that Sliver or something?
Okay, right.
When they've got video cameras, yeah. I'm just looking onto everybody's world and just seeing what people are getting up to. It's nought wrong with that.
Brilliant.
That's why I like washing up.
Ricky laughs
Jingle plays
Chris has emailed a mantra for Karl, we were talking about famous mantras and sayings and things. "Never has a Manc said so much to so many, that means so little."
Brilliant.
So you can have that on your headstone.
Your little round headstone.
Rupert's in the Isle of Man. He says, "I don't know if you knew this, Karl, but apparently octopus's testicles are located in their heads."
Yeah. But then to me, that isn't that amazing, because at the end of the day an octopus, really, all it is is a head.
Ricky bursts laughing
So everything it's got, has to be in the head!
Has to be in the head. It would look daft if they dangled down below. Alright? So all it is is-- I mean, there's a lot--
It looked daft if they dangled down below. There's- I'm wondering again, that's-- I don't think you should start sending them in, but that could almost be the B-side to "I could eat a knob at night"
A B-side to "I could eat a knob at night"
James Round says: "Karl, if you could be anyone in the world, who would it be?"
Dead or alive?
Why would you choose to be a dead person?!
Steve laughs
No, but sometimes, like... There's people who are now dead, but everybody raves about them.
Like who?

But are you saying... But he wants you to live that life, not have been that person? Are you saying that if you chose Napoleon, you'd be Napoleon, but you'd be back to life walking around now on the bus, or it'd be the 18th century or what? What are you saying?
What I mean is, if--
Oh, just answer the question! Who would you be and why?! It's someone you admire or you think had a good life... Just answer the question!
What I mean is, it's good to be remembered. Like Winston Churchill is remembered.
Yeah
As being a decent bloke. But I won't want the hassle that he had. So I don't want to live his life.
Right.
But it's good to be.
You'd like to be Winston Churchill, but you'd like to have a paper round instead of...
...Saving the world.
Yeah.
That's- that's what I mean, but is he saying who would have I wanna -- Whose job would I want to take on?
Ahh...It's not that complicated!
The question is this: "If he could be anyone in the world, who would Karl be?" That's the question. That's all the information I've got.
A lot of responsibility on a lot of jobs, isn't there?
Some of the names flowing through your head now?
I was thinking... Bruce Willis.
Ricky bursts out laughing
I never expected that! I never expected that!
So his responsibility, in your mind, is what? Saving people who are trapped in a building with terrorists?
Well, yeah, maybe, you know, his worries are different worries. With, you know, people who have a lot of money... come... other worries.
Yeah.
I mean, so Bruce Willis, he's always going on these marches isn't he? Saying, stop war and all that-
I don't know.
Mainly because he's got, you know, he's got more, more to lose, if there's a war, he's got loads of houses. One of them's gonna get damaged.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Whereas if you're poor, you've got the one house, if there's a war it's like "Oh, just end it all for me then, I'm sick of it anyway!"
Do you know what I mean?
Yeah.
With-- with successful life, and happy life, there's more for you to lose is what I'm saying.
Right.

Like at the moment, because I've finished a job, that's... That I've been at for ten years, right? I finished working there. So suddenly I've got-- Me timetables a bit out, and I haven't got enough of a routine. And I'm a man who likes to know what I'm doing.
Yeah.
So now suddenly...
Five until seven: Washing up. With no thumbs.
I like, I like-- I've sort of turned into, like, an old person, where the little jobs that you shouldn't enjoy... And now the main event.
Hold on though. So how old are you? You're 31, aren't you?
32, and you're pottering around, not knowing what to do with yourself.
Well, like yesterday, Suzanne's shoes needed to go to the cobblers, right?
(laughing) I haven't heard the word "cobblers"--
I didn't even know cobblers still existed.
I only ever see that in Christmas films made by Disney.
Well, I had to go and do that. And that suddenly--
'Cause last time, last time, you were going to the toffee shop
(laughing) Yeah!
And then you went to the cobblers. Next week it's the candlestick maker.
But all I mean is that suddenly is a nice little day out. I'm sort of putting my coat on, going, right, I'll go and see the cobbler now and go and have a chat.
Tell me about the cobbler.
You didn't come back with three magic beans, did you?
No, the cobbler's, cobbler's all right. He's, you know, he's doing, he's cobbling.
He's cobbling all day.

Have I told you about, uh, my uncle Alf, who was a cobbler? No, I'm sure I told you about him. He's the one who lived in, like, a bedset. And he had two tellies. He had, he had, like, one that, that the sound didn't work on one that the picture didn't. But both together, it worked. So as long as he was watching the, right, the same channel on both, sound came out of one telly and he'd watch the picture on the other.
Brilliant.
And he slept in like, a rubber dinghy. Right?
But he was, whoa, you can't just let that slide. Why did she go to rubber dinghy?
He just like boats and stuff and.
Sort of, yeah, I like boats, but they're better on the water. Beds are better to sleep on. Boats are better to sail on.
Well, he just, he just had it in there. It's a bed set. It was really tight space. Got this. He's got this.
He moved into a dinghy. Sit.

He's got this dinghy. So he's thinking, well, rather than it get in the way, I might as well use it. Yeah, but he was a, he was a cobbler. And he so, like, repair, like, my shoes and that. Right? But it always sort of overdo him, like, fancy do, you know, like, pimp my ride on MTV.
Yeah.
Because he does up shoes. It go mental on him.
What do you mean? There was at the stereo.
Yeah, well, no horns.
Here comes the stripes.
Here comes Mister Pilkington. He's got the fastest shoes in the land.

No, it just makes shoes that would last forever. So instead of putting, like, one sole on, it, put about five on. So you, it looked like one of them built up shoes that you never see. It just put loads of stuff up. Did last forever, but they did.
But they look like the pedic shoes.

Yeah, yeah, it just like the, suddenly I was like six foot seven whenever he'd sort of sorted my shoes out. But he's a cobbler and, you know, it's work that's, that's always, always there for you in it.
I suppose so.
So you went out with. To take Suzanne's shoes to the cobbler?
Yeah. So that's it.
Yeah.

So I just took him to the cobblers and that. And that. That was a, like a nice little job for the day. I got a leaflet through the door saying, you know, if you want to walk a dog, you know, the rates are good. I don't know what they, what they pay in that, but I got a little letter in my little letter box saying, you know, if you, if you free in the day, what they pay you to walk, they pay you to walk a dog in that. And I thought, if I do that and get a paper round, two in one.
Sorry, you just went from a job, right, where you were the head of production at a radio station. Dare I say it, on I. Can I discuss your.
Well, it was all right wage.
It was very good.
I wasn't happy. So it's pointless.
No, I know that. But to go from the head of a department on a lot of money to walking dogs and doing a paper round, I don't know.
But it's about being happy, isn't it?
I know that's commendable if that's true, but okay, that makes you happier.

Well, I haven't walked the dog yet, but I'm just saying, if I do, I mean, I'm not taking it if it's raining. I'm just thinking, if it's a nice, sunny day and I fancy a pottery, I'll go around to her and say, well, how much are you paying? I'll take the dog a walk.
But I can't believe some of the words that have cropped up in this. It's 2006 now. Potter Cobbler's toffee shop. It's very, very strange.
Do you live in Narnia?
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.

A lot of people are sort of emailing in sort of brainy stuff, right? Which, you know, the more the merrier. I'm happy getting all this stuff and if, you know, it grabs me, I, I'll run it by you and you can sort of tell me about in that. And getting a lot of stuff about philosophy.
Oh, yeah.
And all that. Disc artists. That's another one that's mentioned on an email.
Descartes, the french philosopher.
Yeah.
What was those? What's your question?
Well, he sort of cropped up on an email. Someone said, what do you think of?

He famously, he pondered his, his own existence. Cogito ergo sum, I think, therefore I am. He was thinking about, he was thinking, how do I know all this is true? Everything around me. He thought, well, I can see it and I can smell it and I can hear it. He went, oh, yeah, my senses can be fooled. I could be dreaming. He thought, well, that's true, I could be dreaming, but if I'm dreaming, then at least I'm alive, at least I have some sort of consciousness. So if I'm even thinking about anything, you know, I am, I exist. I think, therefore I am. Cogito ergo sum.

But we don't need to know the latin bit. Why is everyone always going back to Latin? It was ages ago. Why is that language always been, and were latin people always in a rush? Because they seem to be like words for full sentences. Why couldn't they just set the time and say what they want to say? And it's just like, what about Plato?
Right?
Greek, right? Now, would you say he's, he's a bright bloke?
Yes, I would. I'd say he's a very, very bright bloke, right.
Let me tell you this, right? If he's that bright, you know, he got killed. No, got hit on the head by an egg.
He's not so clever that, is he?
What's the story with the egg?
He was, he was on holiday or something, right? And he was on holiday.
Greece probably.
He was having a walk about and a bird was flying over the. Over east, over.
So this bird was what, a great orc? What, what, so what size bird killed him with his egg?
It was a big one. Yeah.
Was it?
And the way they used to crack.
An ostrich on a hang glider, the.
Way they used to crack the eggs open to let the kids out. They used to drop them on rocks.
What bird is this dropping its egg to let the kids out? You're a maniac. You are a maniac.

And Plato had a little bald head, right? So from the top, the bird's there looking down and it goes, oh, there's, there's a little rock. I'll drop the egg, hit him on the head, killed him. Now this is what I was saying before about.
I mean, I'm letting too much go now because I'm so desensitized to his nonsense. I let him go. The bird saw Plato and said, there's a rock down there.
Well, if he stopped, if these birds are killing people with bald heads, you've got to be terrified.
So. But listen, this is what I'm saying, though, right before, about knowledge and how knowledge is hassle or success.
That's that. Now, I think that was Newton. Knowledge is hassle.
Now what. But why, why is Plato's intelligence got anything to do with the fact that this bird dropped it?

Because he was intelligent and he's probably earning a nice few quid by giving out whatever messages he gave out. He could afford to go on holiday to exotic places. If he was working in a factory, he wouldn't have been on this beach with big birds dropping eggs is what I'm saying. So in a way, it backfired. His knowledge killed him.
And that, I think, was Kierkegaard. His knowledge killed him.
That's. I mean, where you got this stuff about him being on holiday?
Well, it was. He shouldn't have been on the beach. He was only there having a break or whatever from doing what he does. It wouldn't have happened if he wasn't on holiday.

Again, I can't remember which show this was that we were discussing this, but we talked about well known phrases and quotes from the past. We talked about Benjamin Franklin. People have. This is an email we've had saying, carl, what do you take by the well known saying, a stitching time saves nine? A stitching time saves nine.
Oh, a stitching time saves nine. Yeah.
See, it's another one that I don't, I don't think I've picked up on a lot of these sayings that are being sort of thrown about Willy nillily.
Willy nillily?
Willy nilly. Okay.
Willy nillily. Yeah.
But again, it's one of them, like, like last week. I've heard of it, but.
But what does Willy nilly mean?
Just sort of like throwing it about all over the place.
What, what do you mean? But what? Someone said. What, what does, what does the term Willy nilly mean?
It just sort of means, you know, carefree.
That's right, yeah.
Okay.
But what does a stitching time save?
You understood willy nilly. So you used a phrase. I mean, you used it. You said it willy nillily, but you sort of got the gist of it. So what does a stitching time saves nine mean?
I don't know.
What do you mean, you don't know? Think about it. A stitch in time saves nine.
Is it to do with sewing?
Well, yeah, sort of.
It's not that clear.
So if you got a jacket.
Yeah.

And the seam starts coming undone. Oh, there's a little bit of seam. I'll leave it. Oh, it's getting worse and worse. Soon your sleeve falls off. So just need one stitch there. That'll do it. If you do it now, later you'll need nine stitches. And that, of course, is an analogy to other things. If you leave something that needs attention or repair, it'll get worse. So do it now, do it in time. They could have said a tile inside time saves nine on your roof. They just used it, you know, a sewing analogy.

But it depends if you're busy at that point, because if you've got something else that needs doing, that means that isn't being done because you're messing about, putting, sorting out a hole in your coat, is what I mean. You can't always do stuff straight away, so maybe. I don't know. I don't know if there's a sort of a middle ground where you don't have to do it straight away, but stitching a stitch sometimes today, say in 15 or whatever, meaning you don't have to do it straight away, but just do it before it gets really bad.

Brilliant. Do you think yours is less poetic than a stitching time says nine, so yours is. This is what you want it to be, a quote. Right. Well, you could do it now, but if you're doing something else, then, you know, we don't do it immediately, but do it soon so it doesn't get really bad. Carl Pilkington.
No, but it's the same. That's the same way I treat most things in life. It's like I never go to the doctors unless it's really bad.

That is sensible. That is very good advice. No, that's brilliant advice for anyone listening. Never go to the doctors unless it's really bad. But that's why a lot of people, particularly working class people, you know, die because they don't want to bother the doctor or they're mildly embarrassed or they don't know symptoms, bad symptoms, go to the doctor if you're not sure what some, like you were terrified to go and have your prostate.
Still not been not doing it.
Why not?
I wish you wouldn't talk about it because now Susan will listen to this and she'll go, oh yeah, you haven't been and start dragging it up again.
But why are you worried about a little qualified doctor?
I don't know what they're doing up there.
What?
They just pop.
They? What are you talking about? They pop their finger up.
That's what I mean, though.
Why?
Well, it's 2006.
Yeah.
Why are they still using the index finger?
What would you prefer, the forefinger or the thumb? Would you.
No, what I mean is we've got.
Or a thumb on a stick. So I'm going to thumb on a stick. You?
Yeah.
Would you prefer it to a mechanical thumb, a robot thumb?
Why isn't it just a little camera or something that they put the camera up?
If they initially discover something, just put.
The camera up straight away.
No, they don't need to. They pop the finger up, feel that the prostate isn't swollen, wiggle it around a little bit up your back passage. They. What are you worried about?
I don't think they need to do that.
Are you embarrassed, are you embarrassed about being in a room with your trousers around your ankles? A little fellow popping up a little bit.
Yeah.
Why?

And the other thing is, it's not just, just that, is it? So you go in there, they check your heart out and that, which to me is the most important thing because that's what keeps you going, innit? You've got to go there. You sat on the bus stressing out, thinking, oh, in less than half an hour I'm gonna have a finger up the arse. Right?
What is the wrong?
And they go in, they check your heart. They probably check your testicles and that.
What's up with that? They take your testicles. Yeah, yeah.
But it's all building. And you've sat there going, oh, soon that will be happening.
Yeah.
That's what puts me off.
So if they just came round when you're asleep, Suzanne just let them in. He goes, he's over there, right? And they crept up and went, bang. You know what you're doing.
I just don't understand why they don't teach you how to do it yourself.
How can I imagine you squatting in a corner with one hand on your bollocks and the other finger up the arse going, it seems to be alright.
Karl, you don't understand the phrase "a stitch in time saves nine", I don't think you should be doing any kind of invasive medical research! In your own human body.
But then-
Who knows what trouble you're gonna cause.
No, but then at least-
You'd get stuck!
Yeah.
You would get stuck.
Suzanne would come out, your fist would be up your own arse!
Ricky laughs
Okay, I think it's probably time - Just let me just check my watch - Yeah. It's Monkey News time!
Oh, chimpanzee that, Monkey News you fff...
Right. Last week we talked about, you know, the one who- Who was who was good at getting up buildings and that, for putting out fires and stuff... Ended up working for the fire department.
Yeah. Not true, but...
Sure.
But if the building had good grippage, he was right up there.
Yeah. It's not true, but go on.
So this week, anyway, it's about- It's more about tall buildings and stuff.
Oh, yeah.
It was this bloke who was a builder. Right?
Oh, yeah.
And you know what builders are like, they sort of move about, don't they, from- from sort of, building to building. Just building.
Well, yeah. Well, once they built it, the building's done and they move on to build some more.
From building to building, just building. Yeah.
So he goes to his next job and that. Right?
Who does? The builder?
The builder.
Yep.
He goes to, like, the boss, the boss of this building... who's building it.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Right. Okay. Yeah. And he says what unto him?
"Do you need anything building?"
Ricky bursts laughing
Okay. Yeah.
Right?
So anyway, so he says... He says, "Yeah, yeah, there's plenty of work going about.
Yep.
He says, we're working on this one here. He said "Get going on it. Like, there's your bricks and your cement and stuff. Get on with it."
Yeah.
So they-
Any plans? No- Eh... Just build!
Just start building!
Yeah. Go up!
They're getting on with it and stuff, it's all going well.
Yep.
Right? But he notices that there's someone working high up.
(laughs) Oh okay. Sure.
On the top bit.
Because do you know, like, there's this girders and stuff on these buildings.
Yeah. And he's still building the bottom bit, which is weird...
And he's still- Yeah well, that's that's the way they... do it there, apparently. Just to sort of speed it up. Work from top to middle- From top to bottom.
Sure. That's-- And that's where? In imaginary lands?
We put the spire on, now we better do the foundations!
Yeah.
And then put some stuff in the middle to keep it up there.
So anyway, he's he's saying to, like, the other workers "Who's-- that up there?"
Who's that up there?
He's working on his own.
Little fella, was he?
The little hairy fella up there?
Who's the little hairy fella up there with a hard hat?
And the other fellas were going "Look, you know, don't ask questions... You know, the boss decides who he takes on, we're happy to be getting paid here"
(laughs) "Don't ask questions!"
Well, I'll see him when he comes down.
So he said, well, it's pretty impressive, you know, the work rate he's doing, the way he's getting from one girder to the other.
